newsitem.title: USA: U.S. spot LPGs mixed in second day of slow trade.
newsitem.headline: U.S. spot LPGs mixed in second day of slow trade.

text.p: U.S. spot liquefied petroleum gas prices were mixed midday Tuesday in the second consecutive day of slow-moving trade, players said.
Part of the lackluster activity is due to the volatility seen on NYMEX this week. In addition, few LPG players are in need of product now that winter has ended.
"Everyone is a bit jittery about crude and that's keeping us quiet," said one LPG broker. Crude earlier today shed its two-week old contango as funds rolled their short positions into the back month.
"It's the burnout phase" after winter, said a Midwest trader. "No one really needs to do anything."

In the U.S. Gulf Coast, Mont Belvieu, Texas, spot propane stayed steady at between 34.25 cents and 34.50 cents a gallon. Conway material was slightly stronger at 34.50/34.75 cents following 34.50-cent deals.
Market players said they were waiting for Venezuela's announcement soon on the winner of its tender for 60,000 tonnes of propane. Offers closed on Monday.

The ethane markets, meanwhile, were lower in both hubs amid little activity and weaker cash prices at the Henry Hub, La., as cooler-than-normal weather continued throughout most of the East and Midwest.
Belvieu ethane purity was down about quarter to 18.00/18.25 cents and mix ws 17.00/17.25 cents. Conway ethane was 14.00/14.75 cents.
Normal butane was steady in both hubs, players said. ((--Laney Salisbury, New York Energy Desk 1212 859-1631))
